{{Quote|There is only one way: to find the Cracks of Doom in the depths of [[Orodruin]], the Fire-mountain, and cast the [[The One Ring|Ring]] in there, if you really wish to destroy it, to put it beyond the grasp of [[Sauron|the Enemy]] forever.|[[Gandalf]] in ''[[The Fellowship of the Ring]]'', "[[The Shadow of the Past]]"}}
The '''Cracks of Doom''' or '''Crack of Doom''' were a great fissure, a deep chasm filled with fire,<ref name="Doom">{{RK|Doom}}, pp. 945-7</ref> in which [[the One Ring]] was forged by [[Sauron]] and was destroyed when [[Gollum]] fell with the One Ring into it.

==Geography==
The Cracks of Doom were located in the '''''Sammath Naur''''', the Chambers of Fire, a long cave with a high roof high up on the cone of [[Mount Doom]]<ref name="Doom" /> on the plain of [[Gorgoroth]] in the land of [[Mordor]].<ref>{{RK|Map}}</ref>

From a dark entrance in the eastern side of Mount Doom, the door of the ''Sammath Naur'', a long cave led inside until the great fissure of the Cracks of Doom cut across the floor and walls of the cave a short way from the door.<ref name="Doom" /> A [[Sauron's Road|road]] led from the west gate of [[Barad-dûr]], the Dark Tower of Sauron, to the door of the ''Sammath Naur''.<ref>{{RK|Doom}}, p. 942</ref>

==History==
Sauron forged the One Ring in the Cracks of Doom in c. {{SA|1600|}},<ref>{{App|SA}}, entry for the year ''c. '' 1600, p. 1083</ref> and put so much of his own force into the Ring that the only way it could be destroyed would be to throw it back into the Cracks of Doom.<ref>{{FR|Shadow}}, p. 61</ref> Such an opportunity came in {{SA|3441}}<ref>{{App|SA}}, entry for the year 3441, p. 1084</ref> after the [[Battle of Dagorlad]] but [[Isildur]] kept the Ring for himself, against the council of [[Elrond]] and [[Cirdan]].<ref>{{FR|Council}}, p. 243</ref>

It was decided in the [[Council of Elrond]] that the One Ring must be brought to the Cracks of Doom to be destroyed.<ref>{{FR|Council}}, p. 267-71</ref> [[Frodo Baggins]] and [[Samwise Gamgee]] reached the Cracks of Doom on [[25 March]], {{TA|3019}}.<ref>{{App|Great}}, entry for the year 3019, March 25, p. 1095</ref> It was there that Frodo decided to keep the Ring and put it on his finger and where Gollum bit off the finger with the Ring and fell with it into the fiery chasm destroying the Ring.<ref name="Doom" />

==Other names==
*''Sammath Naur'' is a [[Sindarin]] name that translates to "Chambers of Fire". ''Sammath'' is the [[Sindarin#Class Plural|collective plural]] of the word ''sam'' believed to mean "room, chamber",<ref>[http://www.jrrvf.com/hisweloke/sindar/online/sindar/dict-sd-en.html Hisweloke Sindarin dictionary]</ref> cf. [[Quenya]] ''sambë''. Note that in the earlier ''[[Etymologies]]'' the [[Noldorin]] reflex of ''sambë'' was given as ''tham''.<ref>{{LR|Etymologies}}, entry STAB</ref> The latter word (''[[naur]]'') means "fire".<ref>{{PE|17}}, entry S '''naur''', p. 38 and entry S ''Sammath Naur'', p. 101</ref>

==Inspiration==
The name ''Cracks of Doom'' also sometimes just ''Crack of Doom'' is a wordplay on "cracke of Doome" (''Macbeth''; IV i 117)  meaning the crack/peal of thunder or the sudden sound of the last trumpet that announces the Last Day. Here, [[J.R.R. Tolkien|Tolkien]] uses "crack" to mean "fissure". Tolkien stated that he suspected he derived the idea for this sense of the phrase from a book by Algernon Blackwood, which he had read many years prior.<ref name="Nomen">{{HM|N}}, entry '''Crack of Doom''', pp. 767-8</ref> 

Although Tolkien could no longer recall the name or specifics of the story, it has been suggested that the book in question is Blackwood's ''The Education of Uncle Paul,'' in which two children take the titular character to see "a tiny little crack between Yesterday and To-morrow", and slip through it.<ref>[[Holly Ordway|Ordway, Holly]]. ''[[Tolkien's Modern Reading|Tolkien's Modern Reading: Middle-earth Beyond the Middle Ages]]'' (2021), pp. 234–236</ref>

==Portrayal in adaptations==
'''2001-3: ''[[The Lord of the Rings (film series)]]'''''
:Elrond is seen leading Isildur to the Cracks of Doom and urging him to throw it into the fire. In the films it appears as a doorway with a long bridge that ends with a narrow cliff, with lava below. Gollum and Frodo fight at the Cracks of Doom before both falling (Frodo was rescued by Sam) while in the book Gollum falls by himself.

[[File:The Lord of the Rings Online - Sammath Naur.jpg|thumb|right|Sammath Naur in ''[[The Lord of the Rings Online]]'']]
'''2017: ''[[The Lord of the Rings Online]]'':'''
:A flashback depicting the creation of The One Ring shows a great ring-forge of Sauron inside Sammath Naur. The location is not accessible to the player and is visited only once again, during a Session Play depicting the destruction of the Ring, in which the player controls [[Gollum]].
